Market-based mechanisms focus on emissions levels or compliance costs to determine the economically efficient solution. A tradeable permit program sets allowable emissions under the program. Market-based mechanisms for reducing CO2 emissions focus on setting acceptable emissions levels or compliance costs, allowing the marketplace to determine the economically efficient solution. For example, a tradeable permit program sets allowable emissions while letting the marketplace determine permit value. Similarly, a carbon tax sets a maximum cost per ton of CO2 for reducing emissions, with the marketplace determining the actual reduction amount. A tradeable permit program or carbon tax sets limits on emissions or costs, allowing the marketplace to determine value or reduction amounts based on uncertainty of costs and benefits. A preference for a pure tradeable permit system or inclusion of a safety valve depends on how one views the uncertainty of costs and benefits.
